ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was exposed to important works in the field.

I became acquainted with contemporary debates surrounding the category of World Literature and World Film. We delved into these debates by reading and discussing film theory, translation theory, critiques of globalization, etc. All of these topics are at the forefront of literary studies today, so I feel very up to date on the state of my field.

I learned novel perspectives to observe the cultural production worldwide in examining the discussion and debate around terms like "world literature" and "world cinema". I had an eye-opening exploration of filmic and literary works from the "Southern" regions like China, South Asia, and Africa, and developed critical analytical skills based on the learning of some recent developments of the neo-Marxist and postcolonial theory.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course covered a wide range of topics. It would be better if we had more discussions about world cinema.
The readings are all well picked, and I feel that there could be more to give students further understandings of this issue. The workload is quite manageable.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it was a wonderful seminar with a great selection of texts and films.
I would certainly recommend this course to anyone interested in World Literature debates, and/or the readership and interpretation of works written in minority languages.
Yes. Discussion of the "world literature" and "world cinema" is timely in our time of globalization of cultural production.
